Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Influence of ppGpp on the Cellular Actions of BipA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The selective synthesis of proteins is crucial for the ability of microorganisms to adapt to, and subsequently overcome, adverse environmental conditions. Exactly how protein biosynthesis is coupled to stress responses and virulence pathways in bacteria is not understood. BipA is a member of the translational family of GTPases and has been shown to be critical to the regulation of stress adaptation and pathogenic processes in microorganisms. Similar to other bacterial GTPases, the properties of this protein are determined by guanine nucleotide binding and exchange, as well as by association with the ribosome. An examination of the ribosome binding properties of BipA reveal an unanticipated linkage between BipA and guanosine tetraphosphate (ppGpp), an alarmone responsible for adaptation to altered growth conditions in bacterial cells. Moreover, evidence suggests that BipA acts as an intermediary between the ribosome and the cellular environment and that its structural and regulatory properties influence how the ribosome responds to changing cellular conditions. This research involves using biochemical and biophysical techniques to understand how BipA accomplishes these tasks at the molecular level. There are at least two BipA ribosome complexes, 70S:BipA:GTP and 30S:BipA:ppGpp that exist in vivo. The first goal of this project is to use protein crystallography, cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) and other biophysical methods to determine the nature of these complexes, map the interaction surfaces between the various components and assess conformational changes resulting from binding and hydrolysis events on the local and global level. The second aim utilizes site directed mutagenesis, deletion analysis, fluorescence and hydrolysis assays to assess the contributions of intra- and inter-molecular interactions to the regulation and activities of BipA. Lastly, a variety of techniques will be employed to understand the biochemical and physiological consequences of the interactions involving ppGpp, BipA and the ribosome. Taken together, these studies will define BipA's molecular mechanism of action and provide a greater understanding of stress and virulence pathways in bacteria.

Broader Impact:
This project has the potential to transform our understanding of basic processes regulating protein synthesis, a fundamental process crucial to the ability of organisms to grow and respond to their environment. In addition, this CAREER award will support research and teaching activities at the intersection of biochemistry, biophysics, molecular genetics and microbiology. Emphasis has been placed on connecting biophysical techniques and microbiological processes especially in affording cross-disciplinary research opportunities for students at various stages of their educational careers. In addition, laboratory modules will be developed to introduce students to fundamental techniques in biophysics. These adaptable modules provide the basis of outreach programs connecting with local colleges and minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When bacteria encounter adverse growth conditions, two main criteria must be met to ensure their survival. The first is that they must safeguard their energy, and secondly, they must rapidly modulate their physiology to compensate for the environmental fluctuations. One way to accomplish this is by altering protein synthesis, an extremely energetically taxing process for any organism. This involves a general down regulation in the rates of protein biogenesis and also adjusting ribosomal activity and production.

For several years, we have been studying BipA, a highly conserved member of the translational family of GTPases that has been shown to be critical to the regulation of stress adaptation and pathogenicity processes in microorganisms. Similar to other GTPases, the cellular properties of this protein are determined by guanine nucleotide binding and exchange, as well as its association with the ribosome. Using a hierarchical combination of biophysical techniques including cryo-EM, crystallographic models of isolated protein in various ligand bound states, and a thermodynamic description of guanine nucleotide binding, we have a comprehensive and detailed analysis of the interaction of BipA and the 70S ribosome. These data point to the requirement of an A-site tRNA for BipA binding. In addition, the unique C-terminal domain of the protein is responsible for the majority of the interactions with this tRNA and thus supports the formation of the 70S ribosome complex. 

The onset of stress in bacteria corresponds to an increase in the alarmone ppGpp and a concurrent decrease in GTP. Results from our dynamics studies using a combination of biochemistry, HDX and MD simulations indicate BipA is a metastable molecule where mutually exclusive association of GTP or ppGpp drive equilibria to alternate distinct conformations resulting in differential binding to the ribosome and constitute the operation of this switch. These unique allosteric relays account for a reverse flow of information from BipA to the ribosome and also explain its role as a GTP/ppGpp sensor. From these data we were also able to identify several residues in the switch region of the protein that act as specificity determinants for ppGpp binding.

We have also been able to define the physiological role of BipA in bacteria. A fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) analysis of a BipA deletion strain indicated increased levels of cyclopropane fatty acids. These data suggest a connection between BipA and membrane homeostasis. This agrees with previously reported observation that BipA is involved in protecting enteropathic E. coli and S. enterica from antibacterial peptides. Based on transcriptome analysis, we believe BipA regulates a number of stress proteins and probably does so by altering the rate and timing of translational events. In this manner, BipA acts as a conduit between the environment and the ribosome and is ultimately responsible for conserving precious energy resources in the bacteria and securing survival of the microorganism. 

This work is significant because the mechanism by which ppGpp controls transcriptional rates in bacteria is well established. It binds to RNA polymerase thereby controlling transcription from a number of bacterial promoters. An increase in ppGpp also causes an overall decrease in translational rates but the reason why is not understood. Our work substantiates a role for an unusual bacterial GTPase BipA in translation and thus may represent a direct coupling of ppGpp levels to protein biosynthesis.

Of the researchers involved in this project, approximately 70% now hold both secondary school and university level academic positions. These individuals took part in the numerous outreach endeavors inspired by this grant including participation in local science fairs and tutoring-mentoring minority students in Hartford. The most successful outreach program is the UConn Early College Experience (ECE) Biology Summer Institute which has become an annual program. For the past seven years, I have offered this professional development workshop to certified high school teachers in Connecticut that teach the equivalent of UConn's introductory biology series. The ECE program is statewide involving ~50 high schools, 53 instructors and 700 students. The three-day workshop features morning lectures, interactive lunch discussions followed by a series of short, hands-on modules. It covers a different topic each year including Protein Structure Determination and Visualization, Biological Spectroscopy, Bioenergetics and Computational Biology. The educators receive a copies of the lecture slides and accompanying materials, as well as a complete lab manual describing the procedures and any modifications that may be necessary for classroom setting. This has been a good venue to inspire both educators and STEM students.
